text: Influence of Group Cohesion on the Behavioral Treatment of Smoking
Systematic assessments of the influence of interpersonal relationship variables on outcome are lacking in investigations of smoking treatments.
The present study undertook an investigation of the influence of group cohesiveness on two multicomponent behavioral treatments of smoking.
Subjects (41 women and 31 men) were randomly assigned to treatment according to a 2 (enriched vs. standard cohesiveness) X 2 (satiation vs. nicotine fading) factorial design.
Enriched cohe-siveness subjects not only scored higher on several indexes of cohesion but tended to be more successful over a short term in modifying their smoking behavior.
Subjects were 41 women and 31 men recruited by posters, letters to employers, and public service announcements.
Mean age was 36.4 years, mean years as a smoker was 17.5, and mean baseline cigarettes per day was 24.7.
All subjects were required to return a physician's consent form to participate in the study.
A $10 fee was required to defray material costs, and a $10 deposit was collected that was refundable on collection of 3 - month follow-up data.
Therapists were two doctoral candidates in counseling psychology (one male and one female).
Both therapists had a minimum of 2 years experience in conducting treatments similar to those employed in the present study.
A 2 X 2 factorial design was used.
Factors were treatment intervention (satiation vs. nicotine fading) and cohesion intervention (enriched cohesiveness vs. standard intervention).
For the most part, subjects were assigned to treatment on a random basis.
However, for logistical reasons the requests of couples and friends who wished to be assigned to the same group were honored (there were five such couples and six dyads of friends).
There was at least one and no more than two relationship dyads in anyone group.
Thus, these dyads were evenly distributed.
Treatment took place in groups of 7 to 13 participants.
There were two groups per condition.
Subjects completed a brief demographic and smoking history questionnaire prior to treatment.
In addition, they were provided with pocket-sized record booklets in which they were to maintain a baseline record of their normal smoking fora period of 1 week.
Each therapist led four groups, one in each condition.
All subjects attended an orientation session during which the therapists introduced themselves and the program.
Treatment took place over a 9 - week period.
The emphasis during the first 3 weeks was on preparation for quitting.
The final 6 weeks were devoted to maintenance of abstinence (see, fora more complete description of treatments).
Sessions were 45 - 60 min in length.
Subjects in all treatment conditions met an equal number of times.

The rationale for this procedure was that greatly increasing the intake of or exposure to an initially reinforcing stimulus will decrease the reinforcing value of that stimulus and/or result in that stimulus acquiring aversive properties.
Subjects attended one discussion and preparation meeting and six treatment sessions over the following 1 - week period.

entities.text: attended one discussion and preparation meeting

text: During this period, subjects were instructed to smoke as much as they could between sessions and were urged to smoke a daily minimum of twice their usual number of cigarettes.

entities.text: urged to smoke a daily minimum of twice their usual number of cigarettes.

text: In addition, the sessions included a 25 - min continuous smoking period during which smoking was the only permitted activity.
Subjects were cautioned not to smoke to the point of either dizziness or nausea.
Number of cigarettes consumed throughout the week were recorded in the record booklets.
The rationale for nicotine fading was that gradual and systematic reduction of nicotine intake could minimize withdrawal symptoms.
This procedure would enable subjects to eliminate a substantial proportion of nicotine prior to quitting and to do so with relatively little discomfort.
Subjects followed the essential procedure described by.
However, no 1 requirements were established concerning nicotine content of baseline brands.
Subjects whose initial brand was already low in tar and nicotine were continued when necessary on a system of filters to systematically reduce nicotine intake.
Nicotine fading took place over a 3 - week period, with brand assignments occurring on a weekly basis.
Subjects met five times during the final week for discussion and activities.
Nicotine ratings were taken from figures published by the Federal Trade Commission.
Subjects could choose among several brands containing required nicotine levels.
Nicotine content was reduced from baseline levels by 30% the first week, 60% the second, and 90% the third.
Subjects recorded number of cigarettes smoked in their record booklets and tabulated nicotine intake on both a daily and weekly basis.

entities.text: recorded number of cigarettes smoked in their record booklets

text: Maintenance included six treatment sessions over a 6 - week period.
The initial maintenance session took place 2 days after the quit date, and a second session was held 5 days later.
The remaining sessions were held at weekly intervals.
Throughout maintenance, therapists encouraged and facilitated group discussion.
Special attention was devoted to analyzing subjects' strategies and experiences in maintaining abstinence and to problem-solving particular difficulties related to nonsmoking.
Subjects signed formal contracts consisting of several elements.
They pledged fora 3 - week period to forfeit money for every cigarette smoked (the amount to be forfeited was left to individual discretion, and ranged from approximately $.25 to $5.00).
Subjects also completed separate contracts at each of the first three maintenance sessions calling for specific rewards for abstinence.
Interventions in this condition included written commitments and several exercises designed to facilitate positive group interaction.

Written commitments focused on three elements: the importance of group support and attendance, the need for self-disclosure relevant to cessation attempts, and the expectation that subjects would provide behavioral feedback to other group members.
Self-disclosure and appropriate behavioral feedback were defined, and examples were provided.

The commitments were primarily used to define important behaviors and outline expectations for group interaction and did not specify timing or number of these behaviors to be exhibited by group members.
These commitments were distributed and signed by subjects at the first meeting following the initial orientation session.
Enriched cohesiveness groups also viewed a 10 - min videotape modeling cohesive interactions.
A simulated smoking cessation group was shown engaged in a number of behaviors indicative of and conducive to positive member support.
Models were shown demonstrating a number of targeted behaviors, including mutual support and reinforcement, self-disclosure, and behavioral feedback.
Facilitators used the tape (presented at the sixth session) as a vehicle for group discussion.
Subjects were encouraged to identify appropriate interactions and to suggest methods of applying similar techniques in supporting each other's efforts.
Behavioral practice trials emphasizing both self-disclosure and behavioral feedback were also included.
These exercises were designed to blend in with and facilitate group discussion.
Self-disclosure exercises were adapted from the "I am" statements published by.
Practice in behavioral feedback was incorporated into these exercises.
Groups assigned this intervention did not undergo special cohesiveness training.
Treatment followed the regular cessation and maintenance guidelines described earlier.
Measures of group cohesion included the Hill Interaction, the Comfortable Interpersonal Distance Scale (CIDS;, and a modified version of a group cohesion questionnaire.
Multiple measures of group cohesion were employed for two reasons.
First, the authors wished to assess different facets of cohesion by employing sociometric, self-report, and behavioral measures.
Second, there is no generally accepted measure of cohesion available.
The CIDS is a sociometric measure of interpersonal attraction among group members.
Interpersonal attraction is an important component of overall group cohesion.

Test-retest reliability and validity studies correlating self-report with actual distance measures indicate that the CIDS is a psychometrically sound measure of interpersonal distance and intragroup attraction.
The CIDS was administered twice: once immediately prior to the quit date and again at the end of maintenance.
This permitted assessment of possible changes in level of cohesion from the relatively structured initial part of treatment to the substantially less structured maintenance intervention.
The HIM also provided an indication of potential evolving patterns of cohesive interactions over the course of treatment.
Starting with Session 6, audiotapes were made of each groups' verbal interaction.
Session 6 was chosen as the beginning point so as to allow the groups to form and become established.
This precluded prepost assessment as the cohesion interventions also began at Session 6.
Random 10 - min segments were selected from each tape (however, anew segment was chosen if the group was engaged in a structured activity, such as assignment of reduced-nicotine cigarettes).
Four segments were selected for each group, yielding a total of eight segments per condition.
Raters were a doctoral-level counseling psychologist and a doctoral candidate in counseling psychology, both of whom had received extensive training in the use and scoring of the HIM.

entities.text: received extensive training in the use and scoring of the HIM.

text: Raters were blind both to condition of the tapes and to each others' evaluations.
Previous research had indicated satisfactory reliability and validity for the HIM.
Compilations of studies indicate an average rank-order (rho) correlation of .82 for different judges and an average percentage of agreement between judges of 91%.
Use of the HIM with various types of groups indicates it is a valid measure of group interaction.
Subjects also completed a Cohesion Questionnaire adapted for smoking treatment groups from the instrument developed by.
This posttreatment measure has been used with various types of groups, and it has been found that favorable outcome in therapy groups correlates positively with scores on this instrument.
Subjects were required to maintain records of all cigarettes smoked during treatment and at periodic followup intervals.

entities.text: required to maintain records of all cigarettes smoked

text: Again, pocket-sized record booklets were provided to facilitate record keeping.
Follow-up assessments occurred during the first week after the quit date, as well as at 1, 2, 3, 6, and 12 months thereafter.
For the first two follow-up periods, assessments were made during regular group meetings.
For the latter periods a questionnaire was mailed to subjects along with a stamped, selfaddressed return envelope.
If subjects failed to return the letter, they were contacted by phone.
Subjects were also required to name three informants who were familiar with their smoking patterns and who could verify reported abstinence.
Following cessation of the program, approximately half of these informants were selected at random to be contacted at about the 1 - year follow-up period.

Although the possibility exists that inaccurate information could be obtained using this verification method, there were no incentives for provision of misleading data following conclusion of the treatment program.
Although preferable, biochemical analyses were not available to the investigators to verify self-report data.
Subjects assigned satiation increased their smoking to 152% of baseline.
Although less than the doubling of baseline smoking targeted in the instructions, this increase compares favorably to those obtained in previous studies.

Furthermore, all nicotine fading subjects reported smoking assigned brands (several subjects did admit to smoking an occasional higher nicotine cigarette, but this never exceeded one or two cigarettes per week).
Facilitators checked subjects' cigarettes against their assigned brand at each meeting.
Outof-session verification was not obtained.
Selfreported abstinence was contradicted by informants for 2 subjects, 1 in the enrichedcohesion satiation condition and 1 in the standard satiation treatment.
In both cases, subjects were listed as smoking for purpose of data analysis.
This decrepancy indicates an inaccuracy rate of 6% (n = 2) for subjects whose informants were not contacted.
Thus, 2 subjects from this group were chosen at random and listed as smoking for purposes of data analysis.
One was from the enrichedcohesion satiation condition and 1 was from the standard nicotine fading condition.
No significant differences were found between conditions forage, number of years smoking, or baseline smoking rates.
Analyses of the CIDS data failed to indicate significant differences at first administration.
At no time was there a significant effect for experimenter, sex of subject, or Experimenter X Sex of Subject on any of the outcome measures.
Data for the two experimenters were therefore combined for purposes of statistical analysis.
Condition means and standard deviations for the cohesion instruments are listed in.
Within-groups analyses were performed on the repeated dependent measure, CIDS.

Although both enriched-cohesiveness conditions (satiation and fading) reported similar scores at the two administrations, the standard conditions evidenced a substantial drop in interpersonal attraction and comfort overtime.
These changes were highly significant: for satiation, F(\, 26) = 8.04, p < .01; for nicotine fading, F(l,24) = 19.78, p< .001.
Between-groups analyses for the CIDS were performed using a 2 X 2 analysis of covariance (ANCOVA).
There was no significant effect of cessation treatment (satiation vs. nicotine fading) on this measure.
The cohesion effect (enriched cohesion vs. standard treatment), however, was highly significant, F(l, 58) = 44.06, p < .001.
The Cohesion Questionnaire, a posttreatment measure, was administered only at the final group session.
A 2 (cessation treatment) X 2 (cohesion intervention) analysis of variance (ANOVA) was performed.
Results were again nonsignificant for cessation treatment but were highly significant for cohesion, F(l, 63) = 18.30, p < .001.
The enriched-cohesiveness groups indicated higher levels of cohesion on this self-report measure.
The HIM data were analyzed by a nonparametric proportions test due to the categorical nature of the data.
Rater 1 analyzed all tape segments, and Rater 2 analyzed 50% of the segments chosen at random.
Interrater reliability was 89.6%.
Results indicated a substantially higher proportion of cohesive verbalizations in the enriched-cohesiveness groups, Z = 10.35, p < .001.
Members of enriched-cohesiveness groups worked harder, stayed on task more, and had higher rates of cohesive statements than did members of standard cohesion groups.
Cohesion effects were also evident within each cessation treatment: Z = 8.88, p < .001 for nicotine fading, and Z = 1.80, p < .05 for satiation.
Abstinence data are reported in.
Chi-square analyses examined comparative outcomes as a function of cessation treatment and cohesiveness intervention.
Effects for cessation intervention were significant at both 6 - and 12 - month follow-ups, * 2 (1, N = 72) = 9.68, p < .005, and X 2 0, # = 72) = 4.51, p < .05, respectively.
Examination of suggests that these effects were due to the dismal outcomes attained by subjects assigned standard satiation.
In contrast to cessation treatment effects that were only evident at the later follow-up intervals, the cohesion factor exerted its major influence during the first 3 months of follow- Note.
S = satiation, NF = nicotine fading, CIDS = Comfortable Interpersonal Distance Scale, CQ = Cohesion Questionnaire.
The numbers 1 and 2 represent first and second administrations of this instrument.

Possible scores on the CIDS were 10 cm (minimum interpersonal attraction) to 0 cm (maximum interpersonal attraction), and on the Cohesion Questionnaire, 8 (very low cohesion) to 56 (very high cohesion).
Significant cohesion effects appeared at Month 1, x 2 (l, N = 72) = 4.25, p < .05; Month 2, % 2 (1, N = 72) = 4.37, p < .05; and Month 3, x 2 (l, N = 72) = 4.59, p < .05.
The significant difference at Month 3, however, again appears to be due to the poor performance of the standard satiation group.
Post hoc analyses comparing individual treatment conditions were conducted for the latter three follow-up intervals where differences seemed likely.
Differences between conditions were significant at 3 months and 6 months, % 2 (3, N = 72) = 8.92, p < .05; x 2 (3, N=12)= 11.79, p < .01, respectively.
These differences appear to stem primarily from the discrepant abstinence rates recorded in the standard satiation condition.
The differences in treatment conditions were not significant at 1 year, although the standard satiation condition still fared poorly.
The results of the present investigation support the hypothesis that group cohesion can affect short-term outcome in behaviorally oriented smoking treatments.
Increasing the level of cohesion above that normally found in the groups increased the short-term effectiveness of satiation and nicotine fading.
Subjects in enriched-cohesion conditions were significantly more abstinent than subjects in standard cohesion conditions through 3 - month follow-up.
The use of multiple measures of different facets of cohesion increases the probability that a valid increase in the level of cohesion was obtained.
Interpretation of long-term follow-up data is seriously complicated by the dismal outcomes attained at later follow-up periods in the standard satiation condition.
These results are at variance with the findings of a large number of previous replications.
Post hoc analyses strongly suggest that any treatment effects after 2 - month follow-up stem primarily from the discrepant data reported by standard satiation subjects.
Interviews with subjects may provide a partial, albeit post hoc, explanation for these results.
Between Month 2 and Month 3, 10 of 16 standard satiation subjects reported a significant stressor in their lives (i.e., loss of a job, major illness, loss of a significant other).
None of the other conditions reported a remotely comparable incidence of stressors, and the number of episodes described appears to be considerably above chance expectations.
Marlatt (in press), among others, reported evidence indicating that most smokers attempting to quit relapse following an experience of negative emotional stress.
Based on this reasoning, standard satiation subjects should have been expected to relapse at a higher rate than subjects in other groups.
Cohesion eifects through the 2 - month follow-up cannot be attributed merely to the failure of subjects assigned the standard satiation procedure, however.
The effects of cohesion were definitely evident through the first 2 months prior to any significant relapse of the standard satiation group.
Thus, it does appear that increasing the level of group cohesion in both aversive and nonaversive behavioral treatment formats can enhance the initial maintenance of abstinence.
Longterm effects of cohesion remain to be demonstrated.
Despite the initial effects of cohesion, substantial relapse did occur in all conditions.
This relapse may have resulted from insufficient emphasis on relapse-prevention techniques (cf. Marlatt, in press).

It is perhaps noteworthy that contrary to the results reported by, absolutely no evidence was obtained indicating greater relapse among enriched-cohesiveness subjects following the termination of the treatment program.
These subjects might have been expected to be more dependent on the group interaction for continued abstinence.

Although checks on adherence indicate subjects did follow prescribed treatment guidelines, the absence of biochemical validation of subject self-report increases the possibility of inaccurate abstinence reports.
Subjects (perhaps those in enriched-cohesion groups especially) may have felt pressure to report successful outcomes.
The unavailability of biochemical assessment precludes checking the degree of possible inaccuracy, but any future replication should include biochemical measures.
